title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods, Improved Governance, and Functioning Rule of Law in Afghanistan

description.narrative: Consortium: Reducing Root Causes of Conflict, Instability, and Irregular Migration through Sustainable Livelihoods, Improved Governance, and Functioning Rule of Law in Afghanistan (with Danish Committee for Aid to Afghan Refugees (DACAAR) and Stichting Vluchteling (SV)- Lead party NRC)

participating-org.narrative: Danish Committee for Aid to Afghan Refugees (DACAAR)

sector.narrative: Relief co-ordination, protection and support services

2. Goal 2: Rule of law - Intermediate Outcome 1

description.narrative: 1: Men and women are exercising their rights and have equal and meaningful access to justice (formal and informal)

title.narrative: 1.a (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report exercising their rights

comment.narrative: As per NRC's outcome data monitoring exercise schedule, quarterly ICLA outcome monitoring is planned in April 2019 and results will be ready in April. Hence, NRC will report on all outcome indicators for January - April 2019 in the next quarterly report.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

Counselling through the ICLA programme empowers people with information about their rights, targeted legal or dispute resolution advice based on their particular situation, and support to take the steps required to exercise or claim these rights. Hence, this indicator refers to the total number HLP and LCD counselling services provided during the reporting period. As such, a total of x individuals were provided counselling services during the reproting period.

During the period under review, NRC had planned to conduct outcome monitoring for this project, but unfortunately was not able to due to the deteriorating security situation and fall of the government explained in indicator 1.1a below. Given the security situation, this period under review was not similar to the period when NRC last conducted outcome monitoring (July-December 2020) in both context and time, given that the fall of the government has disrupted the legal context of the country. Thus, NRC has assessed it would be innacurate to apply those findings to this quarter under review. NRC intends to conduct outcome monitoring as soon as practical in the remaining quarter of the project, security conditions pending, and proposes to use the findings of that outcome monitoring exercise to measure this indicator for both the third and fourth quarters of 2021 and outline this in the report for the last quarter.

During the period under review, this project remained suspended by the donor, but NRC instigated an outcome monitoring exercise for the last year of the project in late December 2021. The exercise is not complete at the time of writing. So, NRC will report on this in the annual and final reports which are due later in 2022.

During this quarter, 1,131 program beneficiaries reported to have exercised their rights. These are the beneficiaries who have received direct legal assistance, including 889 beneficiaries receiving LCD legal assistance and 242 beneficiaries receiving legal assistance on HLP.

dimension.name: Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

comment.narrative: During this quarter, 179 (85%) of beneficiaries reported taking follow-up actions to exercise their rights. This is the sum of all ICLA beneficiaries (HLP, LCD legal assistance and counselling) whose cases were resolved, either through support from NRC or through their own follow-up actions. Authorities issued legal documents for 85 % of beneficiaries, thus a large majority had a positive outcome.

During this quarter, from 904 counseling and legal assistance beneficiary, 689 program beneficiaries reported to have exercised their rights. These are the beneficiaries who have received direct legal assistance, including 201 beneficiaries receiving LCD legal assistance and 488 beneficiaries receiving legal assistance on HLP.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This indicator is measured through a wider ICLA programming outcome monitoring survey exercise, using a number of questions. When looking at beneficiary counseling beneficiaries who take follow-up action after receiving counseling to secure either housing, land and property rights, or legal and civil identify documents, the project is on track to overachieve this indicator, 88% of both HLP and legal identity counseling beneficiaries reported that they had taken action to approve relevant to resolve their housing land and property issues. 89% of legal assistance beneficiaries reported that they had been issued a legal identity document as a result of NRC’s legal assistance, whilst 71% of HLP legal assistance beneficiaries reported that a decision had been reached and they had obtained security of tenure either through a formal or informal justice system, or a combination of both. Overall, the project is on track to meet this indicator.

This indicator is measured through individuals interviewed among the sampled counselling beneficiaries (both HLP and LCD) who report to have taken appropriate action to exercise their HLP and LCD rights after receiving counselling services from NRC. NRC applied the formula used in the outcome monitoring conducted in February where NRC interviewed 122 beneficiaries of the counselling services; 59% (72 individuals) out of the 122 respondents reported to have taken appropriate actions to exercise their rights related to HLP and LCD after receiving counselling services. This includes approaching the Population Registration Department (PRD) to obtain Tazkera as well as filing a case with the court claiming their HLP rights based on the counselling they had received from NRC.
NRC applied the findings of this outcome monitoring to the quarter under review concluding that 97 beneficiaries (39.5% female) exercised their rights which represents 59% of the total 165 HLP and LCD counselling beneficiaries reached in the reporting period.

This indicator is measured through individuals interviewed among the sampled counselling beneficiaries (both HLP and LCD) who report to have taken appropriate action to exercise their HLP and LCD rights after receiving counselling services from NRC. NRC applied the formula used in the outcome monitoring conducted in July where NRC interviewed 242 beneficiaries of the counselling services; 75% (181 individuals) out of the 242 respondents reported to have taken appropriate actions to exercise their rights related to HLP and LCD after receiving counselling services. This includes approaching the Population Registration Department (PRD) to obtain Tazkera as well as filing a case with the court claiming their HLP rights based on the counselling they had received from NRC.
NRC applied the findings of this outcome monitoring to the quarter under review concluding that 100 beneficiaries (38% female) exercised their rights which represents 75% of the total 133 HLP and LCD counselling beneficaries reached in the reporting period.

This indicator is measured through sampled beneficiaries of counselling services (both HLP and LCD) who report to have taken appropriate actions to obtain civil documentation or exercise their HLP rights after receiving counselling services. In other words, the denominator for this indicator is total of the beneficiaries who have received counselling services, and the numerator is only those who report to have taken appropriate actions after receiving counselling. During this month, NRC conducted an outcome monitoring exercise covering the period of Jan-June 2020, where NRC interviewed 242 counselling beneficiaries for this indicator. The data shows that 75% of them (181 indidviduals- 48% female) have exercised their rights after receieving counselling from NRC. Based on the new M&E method for this project, NRC applies the result of the interviews with the sampled beneficiaries to the overall counselling beneficiaries reached in during the period monitored. Thus we can say that 385 individuals (28% female) out of total 512 counselling beneficiaries have been reached for this indicator for the period of Jan-June 2020.

title.narrative: 1.b (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who make claims before justice providers.

comment.narrative: 1500 represents 23% of programme beneficiaries, from which 47% are women
911 = 98% achieved

As per NRC's outcome data monitoring exercise schedule, quarterly ICLA outcome monitoring is planned in April 2019 and results will be ready in April. Hence, NRC will report on all outcome indicators for January - April 2019 in the next quarterly report.

During the period under review, NRC had planned to conduct outcome monitoring for this project, but unfortunately was not able to due to the deteriorating security situation and fall of the government explained in indicator 1.1a below. Given the security situation, this period under review was not similar to the period when NRC last conducted outcome monitoring (July-December 2020) in both context and time, given that the fall of the government has disrupted the legal context of the country. Thus, NRC has assessed it would be innacurate to apply those findings to this quarter under review. NRC intends to conduct outcome monitoring as soon as practical in the remaining quarter of the project, security conditions pending, and proposes to use the findings of that outcome monitoring exercise to measure this indicator for both the third and fourth quarters of 2021 and outline this in the report for the last quarter.

During the period under review, this project remained suspended by the donor, but NRC instigated an outcome monitoring exercise for the last year of the project in late December 2021. The exercise is not complete at the time of writing. So, NRC will report on this in the annual and final reports which are due later in 2022.

During this quarter, 1,131 (889 beneficiaries receiving LCD legal assistance and 242 beneficiaries receiving legal assistance on HLP) program beneficiaries reported to have made claim before justice providers, whether formal justice system (court, Justice department, Population Registration Department) or informal justice system (local shura and Jergas). These are the beneficiaries who have received direct legal assistance, including 889 beneficiaries receiving LCD legal assistance and the rest legal assistance on HLP.

During this quarter, 689 (201 beneficiaries receiving LCD legal assistance and 488 beneficiaries receiving legal assistance on HLP) program beneficiaries reported to have made claim before justice providers, whether formal justice system (court, Justice department, Population Registration Department) or informal justice system (local shura and Jergas). These are the beneficiaries who have received direct legal assistance on HLP and LCD.

NRC will report on this indicator on at the end of the operational year NRC Afghanistan, particularly its ICLA and M&E teams, is currently in the process of strengthening its outcome monitoring tools and associated methodological guidance, including the outcome indicators outlined in this project. The team will be finalising the tools in April 2018 and will start conducting outcome monitoring for all relevant activities across all ICLA projects on a regular basis effective from May 2018. The Country Office will thus share results against outcome indicators in the upcoming annual report.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This indicator is calculated by summing the number of HLP and LCD legal assistance cases opened during the project period. As such, during the period under review, 637 (256 HLP; 381 LCD) cases were opened.

This indicator is measured through individual interviews with the sampled beneficiaries of the counselling services on HLP and LCD, who report to have opened cases before the justice system after receiving counselling services and through counting the total beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases opened. In the above mentioned outcome monitoring, NRC monitored this indicator for the period of Jan-June 2020. In this monitoring, NRC interviewed 229 counselling beneficiaries, out of whom 79% (181 individuals-29% female) reported to have claimed their rights before justice providers after receiveing counselling serives from NRC. Based on the new M&E methods, NRC applies the result of the sampled beneficiaries to the overall counselling beneficiaries reached over the monitored period. Thus we can say that 79% (404 individuals) of the total counselling beneficiaries (512) between Jan-June have exercised their rights. This figure plus 2,156 beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases in the same period make 2,560 beneficiaries (47% female) as the achievement for this indicator for the last two quarters (Jan-June 2020).
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This indicator measures legal counseling and legal assistance beneficiaires whose legal identity or HLP disputes have been resolved through formal or informal justice institutions.To date, 40% of the ICLA HLP legal assistance cases have been resolved either through the formal justice system or through the jirga/ shura court (informal justice system).

This indicator measures the total beneficiaries of HLP and LCD legal cases opened as well as the HLP and LCD counseling beneficiaries who have opened a case before the justice system after receiving counseling from NRC. Data collected during the outcome monitoring conducted in February 2021 indicates that 9 (7%) out of 122 counseling beneficiaries opened cases before the justice system after receiving counseling from NRC.
While applying the same formula during the period under review, a total of 560 beneficiaries (53% female) have made claims before the justice providers which represents the total beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases opened in this period (551 individuals) plus 7% (12 individuals) of the total HLP and LCD counseling beneficiaries in the same period which makes 78% of the total counseling and legal assistance beneficiaries on HLP and LCD reached in this period.

This indicator measures the total beneficiaries of HLP and LCD legal cases opened as well as the HLP and LCD counselling beneficiaries who have opened a case before the justice system after receiveing counselling from NRC. Data collected during the outcome monitoring conducted in July 2020 indicates that 130 (82%) out of 158 counselling beneficiaires opened cases before justice system after receiving counselling from NRC.
While applying the same formula during the period under review, a total of 637 beneficiaries (40% female) have made claims before the justice providers which represents he total beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases opened in this period plus 82% (109 individuals) of the total HLP and LCD counselling beneficiaries in the same period which makes 96% of the total counselling and legal assistance beneficiaries on HLP and LCD who made claims before the justice providers in this period.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This quarter 134 (64%) of HLP and LCD legal asssitance and counselling beneficiaries reported that they either took action on their own or received legal assistance in resolving their disputes through formal or informal justice institutions.

title.narrative: 3. Goal 2 Rule of law - Intermediate Outcome 2

description.narrative: Intermediate Outcome 2: Formal and informal justice institutions are increasingly able to deal effectively and fairly with disputes

title.narrative: 2.b (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report that formal, semi-formal, and informal justice institutions have settled their disputes in an accountable manner.

comment.narrative: 2,433 represents 37% of beneficiaries from which 40% are women
Target for the full project implementation

Achievement against this indicator considers the number of legal HLP and LCD cases closed during the reporting period, which are a total of 39 LCD and HLP cases, reaching 169 individuals . The target for this indicator was also set based on the assumption that 46% of total project beneficiaries, which includes those benefitting from information sessions and capacity building trainings, would have closed cases. However, operational realities indicate that it is more realistic to expect that 46% of open cases will be closed during the reporting period. As a result, this target will be revisited and adjusted accordingly during the 2019 annual planning expected to take place in Q4 2018. The indicator was also monitored through an interview with 69 project beneficiaries (20% female) in March 2018 as part of a wider ICLA programming outcome monitoring survey exercise. The interviewees were requested whether their legal concerns and disputs were resolved in an accountable manner to which, 39 individuals mentioned it was resolved fairly, 16 said it was partially fair, and 10 persons indicated limited confidence on the accountability.

As per NRC's outcome data monitoring exercise schedule, quarterly ICLA outcome monitoring is planned in April 2019 and results will be ready in April. Hence, NRC will report on all outcome indicators for January - April 2019 in the next quarterly report.

During the period under review, NRC had planned to conduct outcome monitoring for this project, but unfortunately was not able to due to the deteriorating security situation and fall of the government explained in indicator 1.1a below. Given the security situation, this period under review was not similar to the period when NRC last conducted outcome monitoring (July-December 2020) in both context and time, given that the fall of the government has disrupted the legal context of the country. Thus, NRC has assessed it would be innacurate to apply those findings to this quarter under review. NRC intends to conduct outcome monitoring as soon as practical in the remaining quarter of the project, security conditions pending, and proposes to use the findings of that outcome monitoring exercise to measure this indicator for both the third and fourth quarters of 2021 and outline this in the report for the last quarter.

During the period under review, this project remained suspended by the donor, but NRC instigated an outcome monitoring exercise for the last year of the project in late December 2021. The exercise is not complete at the time of writing. So, NRC will report on this in the annual and final reports which are due later in 2022
Target for the full project implementation

During this quarter, 20% of respondents reported that their cases had been resolved by the justice system in a fair way, whilst the majority felt that justice actors ( formal and informal) were either biased or unfair in their decisions.

NRC did not monitor this indicator during this quarter as the program is working on modifying and revising the M&E and data collection method. NRC will ensure that this indicator along with other indicators is included in the next round of the outcome monitoring exercise which will take place before March 2020.

NRC did not monitor this indicator during this quarter due to simplifying of the NRC M&E outcome monitoring questionnaire. NRC will ensure that this indicator is included in the next round of the outcome monitoring exercise.

NRC did not monitor this indicator for this quarter, as the program did an overall outcome monitoring for the year 2019 in the month of March. The data is under analysis and the report would be shared in the annual report for the year 2019.
Target for the full project implementation

This indicator is measured through a wider ICLA programming outcome monitoring survey exercise, last conducted in September 2018. 66% of survey respondents reported that their legal issues were settled through the formal or informal justice system in a fair manner, the process was neither biased nor corrupt, with 17% of these reporting that the formal or informal justice system settling their case were fair and that they were neutral and competent.

This indicator measures the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases closed as well as counselling cases closed, who reported settling their disputes through the formal, semi-formal and informal justice institutions in an accountable manner. The denominator for this indicator is the total beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases closed and the counselling services beneficiaires who resolved their cases after receiving counselling services, while the numerator represents beneficiaries who report successful resolution of their disputes in an accountable manner.
The July outcome monitoring exercise indicated that 50% (176 individuals) out of 354 counselling and legal assistance beneficiaries settled their disputes in an accountable manner. Accountability is assessed based on factors such as timely processing of the cases; provision of fair justice; abscence of corruption/fraud etc. In applying the same formula during the period under review, a total of 277 beneficiaries (45% female) settled their disputes through the formal, semi-formal and informal justice institutions in an accountable manner. This figure represents 50% (231 individuals) of the total legal assistance cases closed in this period plus 46 counselling beneficiaries, who represent 50% of those who have opened and resolved cases before the justice system after receiving counselling from NRC

This indicator measures the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases closed as well as counselling cases closed, who reported settling their disputes through the formal, semi-formal, and informal justice institutions in an accountable manner. The denominator for this indicator is the total beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases closed and the counseling services beneficiaries who resolved their cases after receiving counselling services, while the numerator represents beneficiaries who report successful resolution of their disputes in an accountable manner.
As previously explained, no outcome monitoring exercise was conducted in this reporting period. The February 2021 outcome monitoring exercise indicated that 46% (97 individuals, 44% of them female) out of 210 counselling and legal assistance beneficiaries settled their disputes in an accountable manner. Accountability is assessed based on factors such as timely processing of the cases; provision of fair justice; absence of corruption/fraud, etc.
In applying the same formula during the period under review, a total of 264 beneficiaries (44% of those females) settled their disputes through the formal, semi-formal, and informal justice institutions in an accountable manner. This figure represents 46% (164 individuals) of the total legal assistance cases closed in this period plus 46% (100 persons) of the counselling beneficiaries who settled their cases in this period. This represents an overall 46% achievement against the indicator in this period.

This indicator measures the sampled beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases closed, and those beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD counselling services who have resolved their cases through the justice system and report that the justice system has resolved their disputes in an accountable manner. NRC achieved 1,193 (29% female) in the reporting period. This figure represents 49% of the total legal assitance and counselling cases closed between Jan-June 2020. NRC conducted a comprehensive outcome monitoring exerices for this project during this quarter covering the period of Jan-June. NRC interviewed 354 benficiaries for this indicator, out of howm 175 individuals (49%- 51 female) reported that the informal jsutice institues (local shura and jergas) have settled their disputes in an accountable manner. Based on the new M&E method for this project, NRC applied the result of the sampled beneficiaires to the overall beneficiaries reached through the legal assistance and counselling cases closed during the period monitored, which is 2,435 individuals. Thus it would be concluded that NRC has acheived 1,193 beneficiares (49%) out of total 2,435 beneficiaries.

title.narrative: 2.a (disaggregated) Number of laws and policies drafted or under development to improve responsive, accountable, and inclusive justice delivery.

comment.narrative: The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 108 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population at the end of 2020, following Presidential Decree 305 issued in 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair. Thus the indicator has been achieved.

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 108 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population at the end of 2020, following Presidential Decree 305 issued in 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair. Thus the indicator has been achieved.

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 108 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population at the end of 2020, following Presidential Decree 305 issued in 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair. Thus the indicator has been achieved.

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 305 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population during 2nd quarter, 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair. Thus the indicator has been achieved

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 305 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population during 2nd quarter, 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair. Thus the indicator has been achieved.

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 305 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population during 2nd quarter, 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair.

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 305 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population during 2nd quarter, 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair.

The Government of Afghanistan issued Presidential Decree 305 on land allocation to the IDP and returnee population during 2nd quarter, 2019. NRC's ICLA team had been involved in developing the decree through advocacy efforts and in close collaboration with the HLP Task Force as the co-chair.

title.narrative: 5. Goal 5 Livelihood - Intermediate Outcome

description.narrative: Intermediate Outcome: (Sustainable) Income-generating and livelihood opportunities (incl. for IDPs and refugees) have been created in a conflict sensitive manner, leading to jobs, income, and more resilient communities.

title.narrative: 1.a (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who started a business/ self-employment activity and sustained it six months after they started.

comment.narrative: 90% (90% of males, 89% of females) Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019.

Based on the survey conducted with vocational trainees, when asked if they had started a business since the training, 70% (168 beneficiaries) did and all of those (100%) that started a business also reported that the business was still generating income at time of the assessment.
Both IRC and DACAAR are yet to collect survey data only from June 2018. Hence, reporting will subsequently take place from 2018 Q3.
DACAAR: end line data collection has been completed for 2021, in both Herat and Kundoz. The analysis of the data and the report drafting will be completed by March 2022.
Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019 or through an end-line survey planned to take place in June 2019.
Will be measured during endline survey in 3rd/4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in 4th quarter.
Will be measured during endline survey in 4th quarter.
Will be measured during endline survey in the 4th quarter. However, it depends on if the project activities resume back. It currently is on hold.

title.narrative: 1.d Number and % of communities in programme areas that have adopted and are implementing livelihood protection strategies.

comment.narrative: (Herat and Kunduz Provinces only) Badghis: Will be measured in July 2020, through endline study Herat and Kunduz: 9 Focus Group Discussions with Farmer Field School beneficiaries represented 9 communities of 2 provinces (Herat and Kunduz). 99% of Focus Group participants adopted and implemented livelihood protection strategies (n= 97; 44 women). The participants were referring to "livelihood protection strategies" as what they have learned during the training and the skills that they have gained and adopted in their general farming practices.

Both IRC and DACAAR are yet to collect survey data only from June 2018. Hence, reporting will subsequently take place from 2018 Q3. Further guidance and clarification will be sought from the Dutch MFA to clarify on what is referred by ‘livelihoods protection strategies’, along with the indicator profile/ definition (i.e. numerator and denominator of the %age) and data source/ method, in order to start measuring and reporting towards this outcome indicator.
12 Communities (70%)

title.narrative: 1. Goal 2 Rule of Law -Long-term Outcome

description.narrative: Long-term Outcome: People have increased access to formal, semi-formal and informal justice systems

title.narrative: a. (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who access justice to resolve their disputes (through formal or informal justice institutions).

comment.narrative: 3,476 is 52% of beneficiaries accessing justice, from which 41% are women

As per NRC's outcome data monitoring exercise schedule, quarterly ICLA outcome monitoring is planned in April 2019 and results will be ready in April. Hence, NRC will report on all outcome indicators for January - April 2019 in the next quarterly report.

Based on NRC’s M&E guidelines for this project, the indicator is measured through sampled HLP and LCD counseling services beneficiaries, who reported opening a case before the justice system and resolved it after receiving the counseling, and through counting the total beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases closed. As such, the denominator is the total counseling services beneficiaries and the total legal assistance cases opened, while the numerator is only the closed legal assistance beneficiaries and counseling services beneficiaries who resolved their cases after receiving counseling.
During the period under review, NRC did not conduct any outcome monitoring for this project as it was viewed more appropriate to conduct an outcome monitoring every six months instead of quarterly. In February 2021, NRC conducted an outcome monitoring covering July to December 2020. During this outcome monitoring exercise, NRC interviewed 122 HLP and LCD counseling beneficiaries, out of whom 7% (9 persons- 3 female) reported having opened and resolved their cases before the justice system after receiving counseling services from NRC. Considering the similarity in terms of the context and time, NRC applied the findings of this outcome monitoring exercise to this period under review to conclude that 7% (12 individuals) of the total HLP and LCD counseling beneficiaries (165 individuals) reached in this period have opened and resolved their cases before the justice system. This number added to the 413 beneficiaries of legal assistance cases closed on HLP and LCD in this period gives 425 individuals, representing 59% of the total beneficiaries reached through counseling and legal assistance cases opened on HLP and LCD in this quarter, which is 716 individuals.

Based on NRC’s M&E guidelines for this project, this indicator is measured through sampled HLP and LCD counselling services beneficiaries, who reported opening a case before the justice system and resolved it after receiving the counselling, and through counting the total beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases closed. As such, the denominator is the total counselling services beneficiaries and the total legal assistance cases opened, while the numerator is only the closed legal assistance beneficiaries and counselling services beneficiaries who resolved their cases after receiving counselling.
During the period under review, NRC did not conduct any outcome monitoring for this project as it was viewed more appropriate to conduct an outcome monitoring every six months instead of quarterly. In July 2020, NRC conducted an outcome monitoring covering January to June. During this outcome monitoring exercise, NRC interviewed 55 counselling beneficiaries, out of whom 69% (38 persons- 18 female) reported to have opened and resolved their cases before the justice system after receiving counselling services from NRC.
Considering the similarity in terms of the context and time, NRC applied the findings of this outcome monitoring exercise to this period under review to conclude that 69% (92 individuals) of the total HLP and LCD counselling beneficiaries (133 individuals) reached in this period, have opened and resolved their cases before the justice system. This number added to the 462 beneficiaries of legal assistance cases closed on HLP and LCD in this period gives 554 indiviuals, representing 83% of the total total beneficiaries reached through counselling and legal assistance cases opened in this quarter.

During the period under review, NRC had planned to conduct outcome monitoring for this project, but unfortunately was not able to due to the deteriorating security situation and fall of the government explained in indicator 1.1a below. Given the security situation, this period under review was not similar to the period when NRC last conducted outcome monitoring (July-December 2020) in both context and time, given that the fall of the government has disrupted the legal context of the country. Thus, NRC has assessed it would be innacurate to apply those findings to this quarter under review. NRC intends to conduct outcome monitoring as soon as practical in the remaining quarter of the project or at the end of the project, security conditions pending, and proposes to use the findings of that outcome monitoring exercise to measure this indicator for both the third and fourth quarters of 2021 and outline this in the report for the last quarter.

During the period under review, this project remained suspended by the donor, but NRC instigated an outcome monitoring exercise for the last year of the project in late December 2021. The exercise is not complete at the time of writing. So, NRC will report on this in the annual and final reports which are due later in 2022.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

During this quarter, 134 programme beneficiaries (64% ) reported resolving their disputes through formal or informal justice institutions. The reported figure is calculated from HLP legal assistance and HLP counselling beneficiaires. For HLP legal assistance, this was the number of those who reported that their HLP legal case had been heard either before a Shura/jirga or state court system and the issue had been positively responded. For HLP counselling, this was measured for beneficiaires who reported that they took action on their own after receiving counseling from NRC, and presented their HLP case before either the formal or the informal justice system.

NRC Afghanistan, particularly its ICLA and M&E teams, is currently in the process of strengthening its outcome monitoring tools and associated methodological guidance, including the outcome indicators outlined in this project. The team will be finalising the tools in April 2018 and will start conducting outcome monitoring for all relevant activities across all ICLA projects on a regular basis effective from May 2018. The Country Office will thus share results against outcome indicators in the upcoming annual report.

This indicator is measured through sampled beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD counselling services, who report to have opened a case before the justice system and resolved it after receiving NRC counselling, and through counting the total beneficiaries of the legal assistance cases closed. In other words, the denominator for this indicator is the total beneficiaries of counselling services and the total legal assistance cases opened, and the numerator is only the beneficiaries of legal assistance cases closed and those beneficiaries of the counselling services who have resolved their cases after receiving counselling. During January to June 2020, NRC reached 2,435 beneficiaries (49% female) under this indicator. This figure represents total beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases closed (2,082 individuals) plus 69% (353 individuals) of the total counselling during this period. In the month of July, NRC conducted a comprehensive outcome monitoring exercise for this project covering the last two quarters (January to June). NRC interviewed 55 counselling beneficiaries, out of whom 69% (38 persons- 26%female) reported to have opened and resolved their cases before the justice system after receiving counselling services from NRC. Based on its new M&E guidelines for this project, NRC applied the result of the interviews with the sampled beneficiaries to the rest of the counselling beneficiaries, therefore we can say that 69% (353 individuals) of the overall counselling beneficiaries (512 individuals) of the same period have resolved their cases. This number plus 2,082 beneficiaries of the total cases closed make 2,435 as the overall achievement under this indicator for the period of Jan-June 2020.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This indicator measures legal counseling and legal assistance beneficiaires whose legal identity or HLP disputes have been resolved through formal or informal justice institutions.To date, 40% of the ICLA HLP legal assistance cases have been resolved either through the formal justice system or through the jirga/ shura court (informal justice system).

This indicator represents the legal assistance and counseling beneficiaries (both HLP and LCD) whose cases are resolved as a result of NRC's services. During this quarter, 1,202 (950 LCD beneficiaries, 252 HLP beneficiaries) individuals of those who have received legal assistance, had their cases resolved. However, NRC could not monitor the counseling services beneficiaries. This is due to NRC working on developing new M&E tools and revising its outcome monitoring methodology as indicated in the annual plan submitted in November 2019.

This indicator represents the legal assistance and counseling beneficiaries (both HLP and LCD) whose cases are resolved as a result of NRC's services. During this quarter, from 904 counseling and legal assistance beneficiary , 817 (358 LCD beneficiaries, 459 HLP beneficiaries) individuals of those who have received legal assistance, had their cases resolved. However; NRC could not monitor the counseling services beneficiaries, as NRC was doing a through outcome monitoring for the whole year 2019 in the month of March 2020. The data is under analysis and will be reported in the annual report for the year 2019.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This target represents 61% of counselling and legal assistance beneficiaries, calculated on the assumption that in 61% of all counselling and legal assistance cases, access to justice will be achieved. With this assumption, and with 35 beneficiaries receiving HLP legal assistance; 65 receiving LCD legal assistance; 68 receiving HLP counselling, and 106 receiving LCD counselling, it is estimated that 167 beneficiaries accessed justice to resolve their dispute during the reporting period.

title.narrative: b. (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report they have confidence in judicial systems.

comment.narrative: 4,705 beneficiaries representing 71% of programme beneficiaries, from which 51% are women
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)
69% of survey respondents reported that they were confident in the justice and administration system to respect their rights.
925=100% achieved

As per NRC's outcome data monitoring exercise schedule, quarterly ICLA outcome monitoring is planned in April 2019 and results will be ready in April. Hence, NRC will report on all outcome indicators for January - April 2019 in the next quarterly report.

Based on NRC’s M&E guideline for this project, this indicator is measured through individual interviews from the sampled beneficiaries of all project services, including counselling, legal assistance and information sessions who report having confidence with the justice system. The denominator is the total beneficiaries of counselling, legal assistance and information session services.
NRC did not conduct an outcome monitoring for this project as explained under Indicator (a) above. During outcome monitoring conducted in February 2021, NRC interviewed 401 individuals, who were mixed recipients of counselling, legal assistance and information provision. The data showed that 90% (362 individuals - 58% of those female) out of the 401 respondents reported to have confidence in the justice system (both formal and informal system).
NRC applied the formula used in the findings of the monitoring exercise to the period under review to conclude that beneficiaries (58% female) have confidence in the justice system. This figure represents 90% of the 2,653 total beneficiaries reached under the project in the reporting period (except for training and mentorship beneficiaries).

During the period under review, this project remained suspended by the donor, but NRC instigated an outcome monitoring exercise for the last year of the project in late December 2021. The exercise is not complete at the time of writing. So, NRC will report on this in the annual and final reports which are due later in 2022.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

During this quarter, 100 (48%) beneficiaries reported that they had confidence that the justice system (informal, formal, and administrative including institutions such as the Property Registration Department (PRD) would uphold their rights.

NRC Afghanistan, particularly its ICLA and M&E teams, is currently in the process of strengthening its outcome monitoring tools and associated methodological guidance, including the outcome indicators outlined in this project. The team will be finalising the tools in April 2018 and will start conducting outcome monitoring for all relevant activities across all ICLA projects on a regular basis effective from May 2018. The Country Office will thus share results against outcome indicators in the upcoming annual report.

NRC did not monitor this indicator during this quarter as the program is working on modifying and revising the M&E and data collection method. NRC will ensure that this indicator along with other indicators is included in the next round of the outcome monitoring exercise.

NRC did not monitor this indicator during this quarter as the program was doing a through outcome monitoring exercise for the whole year 2019 during last month. The data is under analysis and will be reported in the annual report for the year 2019.

This indicator is measured through individual interviews with the sampled beneficiaries of all project services, including counselling, legal assistance and information sessions who report to have confidence on the justice system. In other words, the denominator for this indicator is the total beneficiaries of counselling, legal assistance and information session services. NRC interviewed 497 beneficiaries, out of whom 325 individuals (65%) said they had confidence in the justice system. Based on its new M&E guidelines for this project, NRC applies the result of the interviews with the sampled beneficiaries to all beneficiaries of counselling, legal assistance and information session beneficiaries for HLP and LCD (5,201 individuals) over this period. Therefore, we can say that 65% (3,380 individuals-31%female) of 5,201 beneficiaries reached between Jan-June have confidence in the justice system.

This indicator measures the total beneficiaries of HLP and LCD legal cases opened as well as the HLP and LCD counselling beneficiaries who have opened a case before the justice system after receiveing counselling from NRC. Data collected during the outcome monitoring conducted in July 2020 indicates that 130 (82%) out of 158 counselling beneficiaires opened cases before justice system after receiving counselling from NRC.
While applying the same formula during the period under review, a total of 637 beneficiaries (40% female) have made claims before the justice providers which represents he total beneficiaries of the HLP and LCD legal assistance cases opened in this period plus 82% (109 individuals) of the total HLP and LCD counselling beneficiaries in the same period which makes 96% of the total counselling and legal assistance beneficiaries on HLP and LCD who made claims before the justice providers in this period.
Target for the full project implementation (from January 2017 to December 2021)

This target is calculated based on 75% of the community sensitisation and information session beneficiaries on the rational that 75% of individuals interacting with the justice system will perceive their interactions as fair and accountable. 1,398 individuals received community sensitisation and information services during the reporting period. As such, the number of programme beneficiaries estimated to have confidence in the judicial system is estimated to be 1,048.5. The indicator was also monitored through an interview with 69 project beneficiaries (20% female) in March 2018 as part of a wider ICLA programming outcome monitoring survey exercise. The interviewees were requested of their confidence level in the justice system to which, 42 individuals mentioned they are very confident, 16 said they are partially confident, 10 persons indicated limited confident, and 12 persons shared they have no confidence in them.

title.narrative: 4. Goal 5 Livelihood - Long-term Outcome

description.narrative: Longterm Outcome: Income generating and livelihoods opportunities to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration.

title.narrative: b. (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report reduced personal grievances [e.g. those related to conflict, instability or irregular migration] regarding income/ livelihoods.

comment.narrative: 82% women, 75% men
85% (85% of males, 85% of females; 80% of youth, 87% of non youth) Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019.

Beneficiaries were asked a set of questions about personal grievances. If they currently (at time of survey) did not feel the need to complain about receiving an unfair amount or quality of income / livelihoods OR if they did but they felt that the local government was taking action to address their grievance and their complaints about receiving an unfair amount or quality of income / livelihoods had recently diminished, then they were considered to have reduced personal grievances. 79% (1,627 beneficiaries) of respondents all three questions were classified as reporting reduced personal grievances.
Both IRC and DACAAR are yet to collect survey data only from June 2018. Hence, reporting will subsequently take place from 2018 Q3.
DACAAR: end line data collection has been completed for 2021, in both Herat and Kundoz. The analysis of the data and the report drafting will be completed by March 2022.
Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019 or through an end-line survey planned to take place in June 2019.
Will be measured during endline survey in 3rd/4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in 3rd/4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in 4th quarter

Will be measured during endline survey in the 4th quarter. However, it depends on if the project activities resume back. It currently is on hold.

title.narrative: a. (disaggregated) Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report ability to meet current and future (next 12 months) household needs.

comment.narrative: 28% women, 42% men
52% (47% of males, 58% of females; 57% of youth, 49% of non-youth) Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019.
Baseline at the beginning and endline at the end of each year
Both IRC and DACAAR are yet to collect survey data only from June 2018. Hence, reporting will subsequently take place from 2018 Q3.
DACAAR: end line data collection has been completed for 2021, in both Herat and Kundoz. The analysis of the data and the report drafting will be completed by March 2022.

During the end line survey 2018 conducted during Q3 2019, respondents were asked about their ability to meet current and future households needs - either fully, almost fully, partially or not at all. The sample of 301 interviewed represented 2,060 beneficiaries: Field Farmers Schools (FFS) 1,820 (24% women, 440), Vocational Training (VT) 240 (47% women, 112). 53% (1,092) of responders said that they were fully or almost fully able to meet current and future needs, 60% men and 40% women. Graduated beneficiaries are now able to support their families’ expenditures and send their children to school with new school supplies and nutritious lunches and snacks. Unanticipated positive outcome: The graduates of mobile phone, electric tools repairing and motor bike repairing VTs said they now receive more respect among their community after starting their business. s an example, members of the community address them as Engineer Sahib, which is a title given for university graduate of science in engineering.
Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019 or through an end-line survey planned to take place in June 2019.
Will be measured during endline survey in 3rd/4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in 3rd/4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in 4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in 4th quarter
Will be measured during endline survey in the 4th quarter. However, it depends on if the project activities resume back. It currently is on hold.

title.narrative: c. Number and % of trained farmers reporting an increased agriculture production.

comment.narrative: (61% women, 91% men)
69% (61% of males, 83% of females) Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019.
Both IRC and DACAAR are yet to collect survey data only from June 2018. Hence, reporting will subsequently take place from 2018 Q3.
DACAAR: end line data collection has been completed for 2021, in both Herat and Kundoz. The analysis of the data and the report drafting will be completed by March 2022.

During end line the survey, farmers who participated in the FFS, 86% (1,565 beneficiaries) said that their yield increased from the previous year because of the training they received. As a result of increased agriculture production, the farmers families’ diet improved and as their income through increased sales of produce in the market. As for female farmers, in addition to increased income, they also gained more personal freedom. Namely the opportunity to work outside the house and participate in decision-making in the household. The farmers acquired new skills, such as preservation of milk, greenhouse cultivation, and they also increased their confidence in teaching gained skills to other farmers. For example, farmers who graduated from vegetable and saffron FFSs have access to improved seeds/corms, irrigation system and new knowledge on how to use fertilizer. Farmers who graduated from livestock and poultry FFSs have access to improved stables and coops, and information about proper vaccination.
Outcome monitoring exercise is carried out on a yearly basis. Thus, the next survey results will be available at the end of 2019 or through an end-line survey planned to take place in June 2019.
